intro: Paepalanthus flagellaris, commonly known as the flagellate puya, is a striking plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Haemodoraceae family and is characterized by its tall, slender stems and long, narrow leaves. The plant produces showy, red-orange flowers that bloom in late summer, attracting various pollinators. It is often found growing in rocky or sandy soils at high altitudes. Due to its unique appearance and habitat, it is a subject of interest for botanists and conservationists.
